notes:
1. Concept

A pressure sensor (or pressure transducer) is a device that converts pressure into an electrical signal. Pressure is defined as force per unit area.

2. Common Sensing Principles

Many pressure sensors work by using a flexible diaphragm that deforms when pressure is applied. The method of detecting this deformation determines the type of sensor:

  • Piezoresistive (Strain Gage): This is the most common type. Strain gages are bonded to a diaphragm. When pressure deflects the diaphragm, the strain gages are stretched or compressed, changing their resistance. This resistance change is typically measured with a Wheatstone bridge.
  • Capacitive: The diaphragm acts as one plate of a capacitor. As pressure deflects the diaphragm, the distance between it and a fixed plate changes, which alters the capacitance.
  • Piezoelectric: A piezoelectric crystal is used to convert the dynamic pressure (stress) directly into an electrical charge. These are only suitable for measuring rapidly changing pressures, not static pressures.

3. Types of Pressure Measurement

  • Absolute Pressure: Measured relative to a perfect vacuum.
  • Gage Pressure: Measured relative to the local atmospheric pressure. This is the most common type of pressure measurement. $P_{gage} = P_{abs} - P_{atm}$.
  • Differential Pressure: The difference in pressure between two points.

solvedExamples.question: Most modern electronic pressure transducers use a flexible diaphragm combined with what other type of sensor to detect its deflection?
solvedExamples.explanation: Piezoresistive pressure sensors, which are the most common type, use strain gages mounted on a diaphragm. The pressure deforms the diaphragm, which in turn strains the gages, causing a change in resistance that is converted to a voltage signal.

solvedExamples.question: The pressure reading on a standard car tire gauge measures:
solvedExamples.explanation: A tire pressure gauge measures the pressure inside the tire relative to the atmospheric pressure outside. This is the definition of gage pressure. An uninflated tire would read 0 psi on the gauge, but its absolute pressure is equal to atmospheric pressure (approx 14.7 psi).
